titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:15. Monday.

Persevering in my determination to refrain from the Garden, as from forbidden fruit, the working part of the day, I devoted the morning to the Diary, the Index and La Fayette— I should also have written one Letter, but the time was not sufficient— It began to rain about noon, and continued all the remainder of the day and Evening— After dinner, I visited the Garden and Nursery for a quarter of an hour, but the steady rain brought me back— Charles came in while we were at dinner— There was a town-meeting at four this afternoon, upon the application of a road, through my land at the foot of Penn’s Hill; but I was prevented by the weather from attending— I read the part of the Military, and Naval Letters of the late War, which contains the despatches and Army Orders of General Brown, all of the Summer of 1814— Also part of the first Volume of Sarrans’s Memoirs of La Fayette; but the whole of his Career during the War of the American Revolution is contained in the first 28 pages, and is exceedingly meagre and unsatisfactory— I am yet wandering in quest of a point of view from which to consider his
character as one consistent whole; but I cannot seize it— We diverted the Evening with two Rubbers of whist. Dr Woodward was here this morning to see our Grand-child Mary Louisa, who was very ill the whole day—
2. V. Tuesday— Squantum dinner party—

The day was moderately showery, and we hesitated about going to Squantum,—but Mr George W. Beale, came in the morning, and urged me so that we concluded to go— We went, Charles, Walter Hellen and myself, in the Carriage, at One O’Clock— It was the annual Meeting of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge— It was held immediately after our arrival— Mr Thomas Greenleaf was rechosen, Clerk, George W. Beale Treasurer, and the same Directors as the last year— I administered the Oath of Office, to the Clerk and Treasurer, and a vote was passed conferring upon the Directors all the Corporate powers of the Proprietors, until the next annual meeting— This has usually been done; but I suggested some doubt whether it could have absolute legal effect— We dined at two— Upon Chowder and other fish— The Company were Thomas, Daniel and E. Price Greenleaf—G. W. Beale Edward Miller, Dr Woodward, Mr Emmons and a Captain Quincy who came with him from Boston—my Son Charles—Lieutt. T. B. Adams and Walter Hellen— Some of us after dinner played a Game of Bowls, and we returned home about Sunset— The rain had ceased, and the sky was clearing up— The child Mary Louisa was much better— Dr Woodward attended her this Morning—we spent the Evening at Cards.
3. IV:15 Wednesday.

Charles went to Boston this morning with promise of another visit next week— Henry Hardwick and Harvey Field were here successively, and spoke of the petition for a road from the foot of Penn’s Hill to Braintree, which they think will be injurious to them—It will certainly be so to my property there— Hardwick proposed to me, to rebuild a ruinous wall from opposite his house to the Southeast corner of my Orchard; and give to the Town a slip sufficient to straiten the road, and render that asked for by the Petition unnecessary; but I did not think it would satisfy the Petitioners— Hardwick told me also, that there was a man who came and cut down a young walnut tree in the wood belonging to me, near his house, yesterday he saw him carry it away, but did not know who it was; and he intreated me not to name him as my informer— Field said that the town, at the meeting on Monday voted to oppose the grant of the road, and appointed the Select men, with Noah Curtis and John M. Gourgas to appear in behalf of the Town before the County Commissioners— But Field wished to remonstrate in his own name, and that I should join him in it, which I told him I would readily do— But I must have a copy of the Petition, to be able to answer it— He said it was posted up at French’s tavern and he would send me a copy of it— The Lieutt. brought his Sister Elizabeth here, who stayed and dined with us— Mary Louisa was better, but still confined to the chamber, and far from well— I was myself, much indisposed with sore lungs a threatened long catarrh, and half-blind eyes. The morning labour was irksome, and on visiting my Garden after dinner, the heat of the Sun was too scorching for laborious exercise. I employed Kirk to prepare the ground bordering on the Eastern fence of my Nursery; where I propose to set out slips of hazel and currant bush by way of experiment; and I planted in a new Earthen ware pot a Squantum Peach Stone, Pear Core, and 6 Apple Seeds— Evening
I was forced to waste at Cards— I received this morning, a printed sheet in octavo pamphlet form with “Author’s respects” written at the corner of the first page; headed “Review of the Character of Jesus.” It is an argumentative attack upon the character of Jesus, his Morals, and his Religion— In the Voltaire and Tom Paine Style— There is a statement that it is sent to the Clergy generally in Massachusetts, and to six or eight laymen on an average, in each town of the State— There is therefore party organization, no inconsiderable expense, and learning and talent, and systematic proceeding in this Crusade of Infidelity— I read the paper suppressing as well as I could my feelings of indignation; and asking myself, what can be the motive, and the end of these things?
4. V. Thursday

Another day of greater than Summer heat, and which unfitted me almost as much for writing, or even reading as for labouring in my garden. I did visit the Nursery, which is in a train of preparation to receive my slips of Hazel and of Currants— My Diary and Index left me no leisure for the character of La Fayette— Mr Beale and William Spear, were here about this Petition for a road through my Land. Spear said the Commissioners had been on the ground yesterday, with Lemuel Humphrey the Surveyor, and had marked out the road; and as we thought it advisable to see how they had marked it. Mr Beale promised to call on me at 3. O’Clock with his Chaise, and take me to the place— He came accordingly, and took me in the heat of a blazing Sun to Harvey Field’s house— He was there with his Waggon, and Auctioneer’s hammer going to sell some Land late of William Wood, deceased, and adjoining my meadow— William Spear was also there, but the road had not been marked, and finding it useless to proceed, Mr Beale and I returned home— Beale and Spear had also spoken to me about the rent of my pews in the Meeting House; several of which have been occupied during the last year by persons who are now, unwilling or unable to pay any thing for it— Beale, as the Parish Treasurer had suffered them to take Seats in them for little or nothing before I took the pews from the Parish, and now they expect to have them as gratuitously. Spear told me there was no person would give the rents marked out in my list— He asked me, if he should get what he could for the year past, and give notice that they must for the future pay rent or quit the pews— I said yes, and that I would lease the pews at any reasonable rate— He said there were two persons who had offered 12 dollars a year each, for two of the pews, which I told him I would accept— Harvey Field sent me a tax Bill for the year 1833 of 389 dollars. 40 cents of which 150 dollars 20 cents are for parish tax— We visited this Evening at Mr Beale’s— Mr and Mrs Emmons, are to return with their family to Boston to-morrow—Cards after we came home. Mary Louisa continues better, but still unwell
5. IV:15. Friday.

Showery the whole day and evening almost without intermission; and the day was devoted to the closet—still with little effect— Two or three times I found occasions to pass a quarter of an hour in the garden, but to as little purpose as were my labours in the House— I filled a Pot N. 14 with [symbols] Horse Plum Stones, Catherine Pear Cores, and Office Apple Seeds— My expedients hitherto for ascertaining the identity of the plant that comes up with the seed sown, and those seeds which will not vegetate at all have almost all failed— A very few of them have succeeded— One of the surest modes of ascertaining is that of planting the seeds in Earthen Pots— This I have practised several

years, and have now nine Pots, with plants growing in them from Seeds and Stones which I planted in them last Autumn, But not having been duly attentive to mark the exact time of planting in each Pot, nor the particular seed deposited in it, I know not what they are, except generally as Apples, Pears, grapes, cherries, one Plum, and one Althaea— I propose this year to be more careful, and to record the peculiar seed, deposited in each Pot, and have numbered the Pots— Of the seeds committed this day to Pot 14. I have reason to believe that the Office Apples will come up; but none of the Cherries, Plums or Pears— At my age these experiments can do nothing more than gratify curiosity, and that to a very limited extent— Had I commenced them fifty years ago, and had the means of pursuing, multiplying, and improving upon them from year to year, I have no doubt I should have made useful, perhaps important discoveries, for the natural History and cultivation of fruit and forest trees— An insatiate curiosity, and untiring perseverance, are qualities as indispensable for this labour, to which I believe that a life, of incessant activity, of laborious exertion, and of powerfully excited intellect might be devoted with profit, pleasure, honour, and splendid success.— For me, the time is past. I can only point the way.— I had a morning visit from Dr Gray of Roxbury; and spent the remainder of the day, in reading and writing upon La Fayette
6. V. Saturday.

Early this morning I went into Boston with my wife, and Walter Hellen. At Charles’s House, we found him and his wife— At ten O’Clock I went to the Council Chamber in the State House where I met a few acquaintance, and many Strangers— It was the anniversary of La Fayette’s birthday and the day fixed for the Commemoration of his Life and Character; by the young men of Boston— A large procession civil and military was formed, which went from the State House to Faneuil Hall, where a splendid Oration of an hour and fifty-minutes was delivered by Edward Everett— He commenced precisely at two O’Clock, and for lack of time, abridged his discourse, perhaps nearly an hour. It was received with universal applause, and in the delivery was often interrupted by long protracted shouts and hand-clappings, of exulting approbation— It was delivered, every word from Memory— His manuscript lying on the table, and he never once recurred to it— The Oration was preceded by a dirge of Handel, with appropriate words in prose adapted to the Music— An admirable prayer by Mr Frothingham— A Requiem in verse—the Words by Grenville Mellen— Music by Lowell Mason—and was followed by a Hymn—words by Isaac M’Lellan junr. Music by G. J. Webb— It was past four O’Clock, when the ceremonies closed, and I went by invitation, and dined at Mr Frothingham’s, where we found my wife and Charles’s— Mr Peter C. Brooks, Charles and Walter Hellen, went with us from Faneuil Hall— Edward Brooks and Sidney Brooks and his wife were also of the dinner party— We left Mr Frothingham’s about seven in the Evening and returned home to Quincy, my wife very unwell, and after retiring to bed quite sick— I met this morning at the Council Chamber the Senators Mangum and Ewing, R. H. Wilde of the House of Representatives, General Macomb, and his two Aids de Camp— Wilde asked me, if I should be at home on Monday, and on my affirmative answer, promised to come out and see me that day— I had received this morning from Professor J. G. Palfrey, two Sermons of his and a Review of one of them, all relating to the University— I thanked him for them, and he thanked me, for my Report on the disturbances, which Lieutt. Governor Armstrong and two or three other members of the Board of Overseers, told me they had received this morning. Mr Parker the County Attorney, said to me that if it would be agreeable to me, he would send in a copy of his argument on the recent trial of Abner Kneeland for blasphemy— I told him I had seen with great interest in the public Journals a summary account of that trial, and
should be highly obliged to him for a copy of his argument— I walked in the procession with William Jackson, the Anti-masonic member of the National House of Representatives from the fifth Congressional District of this Commonwealth, who as we were walking, asked me what they should do at their Antimasonic State Convention, which is to meet next Wednesday at Boston to nominate Candidates for the Offices of Governor and Lieutt. Governor for the ensuing year— I told him I knew not what they should do, and was too certain they would not do what I should say— After some further conversation I said, I had some weeks since said to one of the leading Antimasons it was in my opinion the true policy of the antimasons to support the re-election of Governor Davis, and wished they would— That shortly after, the Gentlemen to whom I had said this mentioned it to another, who intimated a wish if that was my opinion, that I should not much divulge it, and I had accordingly forborne to speak upon the subject— Mr Jackson did not concur with me in opinion, and thought it was impossible that the Anti-masons should support the re-election of Mr. Davis— I said the only alternatives were to vote for Morton, which would merge AntiMasonry in Jacksonism; or to nominate a candidate of their own with a certainty of defeat. We discussed amicably this question till we came to the door of Faneuil Hall, without approaching to an agreement— I received at Boston this morning a Letter from C. H. Pasley Coll. of Royal Engineers in England, dated Chatham 20. June 1834— He has been publishing a work upon Weights and Measures, of which he presents me with a Copy, (but that was not with the Letter) and says he has done Justice to my Report made to the Senate of the United States in 1821. acknowledging that my historical account of English Weights and Measures, is more correct than any that has been given by any English writer; including the Reports of Committees of the House of Commons— This acknowledgment thirteen years after the publication of my Report was very gratifying to me— If either of my children or any of theirs should ever read this page, let me tell him that Coll. Pasley’s testimonial to that single point, the accuracy of my historical investigation of English weights and measures, is but one of many discoveries which he will find in my Report, if he will have the courage and perseverance to read, and examine it as he reads— He will find the History not only of English, but of Hebrew, Greek, Roman, and French weights and measures, traced to their origin, in the natural history of man and of human Society, such as he can find in no other writer, antient or modern— He will find a philosophical discussion of the moral principles involved in the consideration of weights and measures, and of the extent and limitation of its connection with binal, decimal, and duodecimal arithmetic, for which he might look in vain elsewhere; and if he should remark that not one of his Countrymen ever noticed these peculiarities of that Report, he may amuse himself by enquiring why and how it has happened— The Report from the day of its publication, has in this Country scarcely been known to exist; and this commendation of it, coming back from England is therefore the more welcome to me— The other Letter was from Charles A. Davis enclosing a London Newspaper, with a very favourable review of Major Jack Downing’s Letters; as gratifying to him, as Coll. Pasley’s notice is to me— Mr Wilde told me he had seen in a New-York paper, mention made of Pasley’s book, and of its remarks upon my Report. On our return home this Evening, Mrs Adams went immediately to bed, very much indisposed.
7. IV:30. Sunday.

My wife after being quite ill the early part of last Night, appeared to be in quiet repose this morning; but she was confined to her bed the whole of this day, with a severe stricture across the Breast, and a racking cough— This Evening she appeared to be
more easy, and took some nourishment— I thought she was recovering, and between nine and ten O’Clock, I went to bed— About an hour afterwards; she suddenly called out to me, that she was ill, and had a fainting fit with distressing sickness. I roused up Mrs Wilson, and Kirk and his wife, and sent Kirk immediately for Dr Woodward. He came about half past eleven and stayed till one in the Morning—at which time the extreme severity of the disease was abating, and the Patient was lapsing into sleep. I then removed into the next bed-chamber, leaving one of the women with Mrs Adams for the remainder of the Night— I had heard at Meeting, Mr Farley, in the morning from Luke 16:10. “He that is faithful in that which is least, is faithful also in much.”—and in the afternoon from Acts 10.38. “Jesus of Nazareth—who went about doing good.”— discourses more immediately practical, though not so elegant in speculation, as those of Mr Lunt— Mr Whitney was in the Pulpit— I read also the third Sermon of the 6th. Volume of Saurin, upon the incomprehensibility of the divine Mercies— In general the posthumous Sermons, appear not equal to those published by the author in his own Life-time— This was an eloquent exhortation of his hearers to Repentance, but the commentary upon the words in Isaiah 55.7. for our God, will abundantly pardon, somewhat startled me— There are truths even in the moral government of the world, which it is wiser to state in general terms than by setting forth in detail seem to bring in conflict with the natural sense of Justice.
8. VI.15. Monday.

My wife was confined to her bed the whole of this day, though recovering from her illness— I rose late and was much interrupted in my business— Captain Souther had given me yesterday a remonstrance to be signed by some of the Inhabitants of the town, against the laying out of the new road from the foot of Penn’s Hill, through my Orchard— It was in Mr Gourgas’s hand-writing, and I signed it with a small alteration The County Commissioners are to meet to-morrow Morning at Braintree—and I told Captain Souther I would attend at their Meeting if the weather should be fair. Mr Thomas Vinson an Officer of the Revolutionary War, came and insisted that the Pension allowed him by the Commissioner of Pensions was not so much as he is entitled to— He had written to me last Winter to obtain an increase of it, but his claim was rejected— He now brought with him his Pension Certificate, which is for 330.67. and my Letter to him of 30: Novr. last reporting to him the decision of the Commissioner against him— He says the pay of a Lieutenant was 30 dollars and of a Captain 40 dollars a Month—and as he was allowed for two full years of Service, 22 Months and 12 days as a Lieutenant, and 1. Month 18 days as a Captain his Certificate appears not to be for so much as he has a right to claim— I took minutes on my sheet of Scraps 2. of these particulars and promised to apply to the Secretary of War again, to rectify the apparent error, on my return to Washington next November— He enquired if I had received any answer respecting the application for the discharge of his Grandson Warren Vincent Thayer, from the Dutch service— I read to him the Letter I had received a few days since from the Secretary of State Forsyth, and the extract from the despatch of Mr Davezac, Chargé d’Affaires of the United States at the Hague, stating that he had made application for Thayer’s discharge, to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, but had not received his answer and if necessary would ask for an Audience of the King— I told him I should have communicated these papers to the young
man’s father, but had been waiting for further information from the Secretary of State— He said he would himself give the information to the father— I had morning visits from R. H. Wilde, and Coll. T. H. Perkins, who brought with him a basket of beautiful Peaches, Nectarines, grapes and a fruit resembling currants, but growing on a stem— After dinner I visited the garden and Nursery: But Blazing Sun, and flooding rain alternately expel me from them and baffle my labours— I set out six twigs of hazel-bush along the western fence of the Nursery, and planted two Perkins Peach Stones in the Garden— Evening idled off, doing nothing— Received 30 copies of the printed proceedings of the Overseers of Harvard University on the 25th. of August 1834 respecting the recent disturbances at that Seminary.
9. V.15 Tuesday.

My wife continues confined to her bed with a burning fever and almost incessant cough— Dr Woodward was here morning and Evening— I went with Kirk to Braintree to attend the Meeting of the County Commissioners, upon the Petition for the new Road. They met first at Arnold’s tavern in Braintree; but I met them on the way to Harvey Fields house, at which point they proposed that the road should commence— I turned back and just as we reached the house there came up a thunder shower, followed by a succession of Showers which kept us there upwards of two hours— Harvey Field was not at home, but his father Joseph born 1749 entertained the company much with his sallies of vivacity against the road— At an interval between the Showers, I went with the Commissioners over the ground of the proposed road through my Penn’s hill Orchard— Of the Commissioners there were Samuel P. Loud of Dorchester, and William Ellis of Dedham—of the Petitioners, Mr Capen and Minott Thayer, of the Committee from the Town of Quincy to oppose the road John Souther, Lewis Bass, Noah Curtis and John M. Gourgas. The Petitioners wanted a different road from that set forth in their Petition—and Minott Thayer, their principal Orator was very assiduous and argumentative with the Commissioners to persuade them, to lay out the road, as the Petitioners now wish it, and not as the Petition described— I stated briefly to the Commissioners that I had agreed with Harvey Field to join him in remonstrating against the invasion of his and my property; and as an inhabitant of the Town, I had signed their remonstrance against it— That for my individual property, I had entire confidence in the Commissioners— If they thought the road would be of public benefit; they would not consider me as opposing it; but as claiming the indemnity for my property taken, as secured to me by the Constitution— Minott Thayer made many attempts to draw from me an offer to give the Land which the road would embrace, in my Lots, and appealed to my public Spirit; to my liberality, and to my old affection for my native town of Braintree; to all which I responded with good humour and caution— The Commissioners then proceeded in their examination of the road, and I left them and came home— They agreed to meet at the tavern at four O’Clock this afternoon, to hear the parties: but I did not think it necessary to attend them there. The showering continued till about 2. O’Clock—and I lost by this excursion a great part of the day— After dinner I visited my Garden and Nursery, but the ground was so wet, and the atmosphere still so damp that I could not work with any Satisfaction— I planted a Perkins Nectarine Stone, Cling-stone Peach, and several purple grape seeds at the North-west corner of the Garden, and transplanted a seedling Pear-tree two Winters old, to their side, taking it from a double one in the opposite patch— Mrs T. B. Adams called this afternoon to see my wife— Her Son John Quincy was with her—recovering from a fever.
10. VI:15. Wednesday.

Mrs Adams still confined to her bed, with high fever and almost ceaseless cough— Charles came out from Boston before dinner. His daughter Louisa, had the night before last a violent attack of the Cholera Morbus, which prevented him from coming out yesterday. Mr Hayden is a young man from Braintree, who wishes to rent upon a lease for five years the house and farm which was my brother’s, and of which the title is now in me; but the use and profits of which I have given to my brother’s widow for her life— I told Hayden he must apply to her— Deacon Spear, with his nephew Charles Baxter was here after dinner, to converse about selling of wood upon my lots, of which there are now only scanty fragments left— The Deacon has been for the last two years much out of health, but is still fond of talking politics, and conscious of his own wisdom and integrity— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here in the afternoon and Evening. My proper occupations are grievously interrupted, not only by visitors, but by petty calls of my private concerns, by the continual anxiety of my wife’s illness, and by the condition of my eyes, almost blind. I wrote this day only one page upon La Fayette, and had not sufficient time for bare exercise in my garden— I began the transplantation of my young seedling trees, which have grown up too closely together— Took up from the elm-shaded North end of the Nursery seven seedling Pear trees, looking above ground quite healthy, but with the taproot of every one of them bitten off, within half an inch of the surface— I set them out again in the Northwest corner patch of the Garden, but believe it not possible that they should live. I transplanted also, several other Apple-seedlings, and one white Beach into a row from a horse-chesnut stake to the fence in the Jargonel pear-tree patch— My seedlings come up in clusters very irregularly, and injure each others growth. I now for the first time undertake to arrange them in rows, and think it will take me at least the steady afternoon’s labour of one Month. There are scattered over the Garden and Nursery, perhaps 30 seedling trees, apparently Buttonwoods which have come up this Season, I know not how; no seed having been planted by me— I staked once this afternoon discovered, with a willow-twig in my old hickory patch Their growth is so slow, that I doubt whether they will survive the winter
11. V:15 Thursday.

My wife continued extremely ill all Night and all this day; and just at dinner time had so severe a turn that I sent for Dr Woodward again, he having been here this morning. He was gone to Boston, but came after his return in the Evening— She was then a little relieved, but has yet a ceaseless cough— He thinks she has a lung fever— President Quincy called upon me, and returned me the mortgage upon my two houses in Tremont Street, Boston, which I gave on the 6th. of October 1826. to secure the payment of the bequests in my fathers Will, to my brothers two elder Sons Thomas Boylston and Isaac Hull— He said he had discharged the mortgage upon the record in Boston; and there now remains only one of the four mortgages which I then gave to be discharged; and that cannot be effected before the year 1838— It is on the House and Store in Court Street, Boston Mr Quincy spoke of the present condition of the University as on the whole satisfactory; though with some qualification— The Prosecutions at the Court of Common Pleas in the County of Middlesex have terminated as he would have wished— One of the young men who were indicted having made full confession, and thrown himself on the mercy of the faculty— The Prosecution had therefore been withdrawn. Another had
pleaded a noli-contendere, and had been sentenced to a fine of 20 dollars upon one Indictment, and 30 dollars upon the other; and the third has absconded. About ninety Students have been admitted in to the several classes— Of the Junior Class, the whole of whom, excepting three, were dismissed as Sophomores, thirty-three have applied for readmission— Sixteen of them have been readmitted, and no decision has yet been made upon the rest— There was some disorder in the freshmen Class, the night before last; by a bonfire made in the College-yard; upon which the faculty met, and closed the term of probation of one Student detected in the act of making the fire— The number of the freshman Class is upwards of seventy, and there will be more than forty finally in the junior Class— I spoke to Mr Quincy of the pamphlet sheet I had received under a blank cover; called a Review of the life and character of Jesus—and asked him if it had been sent to him— He said he had not received it—but that he had received several other pamphlets of the same stamp— I asked him if he knew who and what this faction of Atheists were; and how they were working— He knew not much about them; but said they had weekly Meetings on Sundays, at the federal Street Theatre; where the most unqualified Atheism was preached; of which he gave me a shocking Specimen. I asked him if he did not think that a steady watch should be kept, over the progress of this Spirit, with a view to counteract its mischievous tendencies— He said he did; but did not know how it was best to be counteracted— He told me that one of the principal persons of the Atheist crew was Green, the Postmaster at Boston— Charles returned this Morning to Boston— I went through my indispensable daily task, but had scarcely half an hour for exercise in the garden and Nursery— I employed it, in transplanting Seedling Apple trees; to range them in rows— My nephew John Quincy was here this Morning.
12. IV:45 Friday.

My wife’s illness continues with unabated severity, though with changes of symptoms, and occasional gleams of more ease, and a partial subsiding of the cough and fever— The distress and anxiety under which I labour affects my own health and much more my capacity for writing. I can command no steady application of mind— The weather of the last two days has been fine, but cold, and my only exercise is working in my garden and Nursery. Dr. Howe, and a young man named Sergeant came this afternoon from Boston, and told me they were about to purchase and become joint Editors of the New-England Magazine, a monthly periodical Journal, hitherto published by Joseph T. Buckingham— They intended to make it political and literary, and they would need the assistance of competent persons in both Departments. They came to me therefore; to ask for counsel, and for any assistance that I might be disposed to give them, for the prosecution of their undertaking— This introduced a Conversation, in which I freely gave them my opinions, and advice— I said I sincerely wished they might succeed; and the reputation of the Magazine they were intending to purchase stood fair, though I was not a subscriber to it, and had seldom seen it— The principal difficulty which I believed they would have to encounter was the competition of similar Periodicals which were almost numberless. No one could tell how many there were; for most of them were so short lived, that they ceased to exist as they came into life, without notice or memorial— The North-American Review had now a standing of some years— The American Quarterly Review of Seven or Eight— But there had been a Southern, and a Western Quarterly Review, both of which I believed
were now extinct, and of the monthly Magazines I knew scarcely one which was worth its cost of paper and type— I thought their greatest difficulty would be the competition with the North-American Review— Mr Howe said their publication was a monthly Magazine, and of a lighter character than the North-American Review— They neither intended nor anticipated any competition with that, but they rather hoped the two publications might mutually aid each other— I finally observed that my necessary occupation so totally absorbed my time, that it would be utterly impossible for me to supply them with an Article for publication, while my present engagements should continue; but I offered to subscribe for their Magazine, which Dr Howe said they did not wish, until I should have an opportunity to judge of the character of the work— They took leave with my good wishes for their success. Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here this Evening— My Grand-daughter Mary-Louisa planted this afternoon a Perkins Peach, Nectarine, and several purple grape-seeds— She had planted last fall a walnut, and remembered it this Summer, with anxious enquiry for the tree, but it did not succeed. I wish to give her more than one chance this year, and that she may have the pleasure of seeing the growth of a tree of her own planting.
13. VI: Saturday Boston Quincy

My wife still continues very ill, and the child Mary-Louisa, is this day quite unwell; with a cold, head-ache and some fever. On the evening of the last Commencement day at Cambridge, there was held a meeting of the Alumni of the University, at which it was voted that a subscription should be obtained in aid of the funds of the University for the purpose of diminishing the expence of education; and a Committee of twenty persons charged with this duty was nominated by Chief Justice Shaw who presided at the Meeting. They were appointed according to the order of the Classes; and I received a notification signed by Sidney Willard Secretary to the Meeting, that I was a member of this Committee with an earnest invitation that I would attend, this day, when the Committee would assemble at the Hall of the American Academy. N. 50. State Street, Boston at 11. A.M. As I disapprove of the object for which this contribution is proposed, I hesitated whether to attend, but to avoid every appearance of disrespect to the meeting and to the appointment conferred upon me by so respectable an authority, I concluded to go—to state with candour my insuperable objections to the scheme, and to decline the appointment as a member of the Committee— I was also commissioned to procure some articles of medicine and for the family, and particularly a house-maid to relieve Mrs Kirk and Mrs Wilson, who by attendance Night and day on the sick chamber, need assistance—for the work of the house I went to Boston in the Carriage, and called at Mr James H. Foster’s and enquired of Mrs Foster if she could procure a woman for housemaid work to go out with me, but she said it was impossible— Thence I went to Charles’s Office, and charged him with all my Commissions— Then to the Meeting which it being half past eleven O’Clock, I expected to find organized, and in full deliberation— I found only 11 members of the Committee there, who immediately after I went in, were called to order, and I was chosen Chairman of the Meeting— Charles P. Curtis was first nominated to act as Secretary to the Committee, but requested to be excused; and Robert C Winthrop the youngest member of the Committee was chosen— The Revd. Jonathan M. Wainwright then stated that he wished to withdraw from the Committee; as after full consideration he could not approve of the application, which the Meeting of Alumni had determined should be made, of the funds which it should was proposed to raise by subscription— He then in a few words assigned his objections to the project as it was voted at the
Meeting of Alumni, and when he finished, I said I ought in candour to say that I concurred entirely with him in opinion— That I had attended the meeting with the intention of offering the same observations and of declaring the same purpose— This gave rise to an amicable debate of two hours, in which Judge Story set forth all the reasons which had induced the Meeting to confine the application of the funds to the object of diminishing the expence of education— In this debate Charles P. Curtis, Leverett Saltonstall, Doctor Jacob Bigelow, Benjamin A. Gould and William H. Gardiner took part— No one except Judge Story appeared to approve this application of the funds which seemed to me a waste of them—a mere bonus to the merchants in Boston and to a few clergymen, throughout the State, to send their Sons to Cambridge, rather than to Amherst, or Williamstown, or New-Haven or Providence for Education; and I likened it to a Stage or Steam-boat competition, in which the parties underbid each other, for custom, till one offers to convey passengers for nothing, and the other to pay them, instead of receiving pay from them for their passage— Judge Story warmly urged Mr Wainwright and me, not to withdraw from the Committee, least it should have so discouraging an effect, as to defeat the whole project— I finally said that if Mr Wainwright would concur in that course, I would not withdraw from the Committee, but without interfering with the measures which the other members might adopt; be fully understood neither to approve them, nor expected in any manner to support them— It was then proposed to adjourn the Meeting to this day fortnight at ten O’Clock, when the subject should be farther considered, and it was voted that the Secretary should give notice of the adjourned Meeting to all the absent Members of the Committee— Adjourned at half-past one— I went to Charles’s Office— The key was in his door but he was not there— Just then the Bells were ringing for a fire; and the Engines were rattling over the pavements; and the People were running to and fro in the Streets with much confusion— The fire was in a Blacksmith’s shop; next door to Foster’s Stable where my Carriage and Horses were put up. It is in an excessively narrow Lane, which was so choaked up with fire Engines, and Hose and fire companies, that I was a full half-hour approaching it by every avenue of access before I could reach it— I met in the Square of the old Exchange Coffee House, Mr Nathaniel Curtis, who told me that Ward N. Boylston was doing well;—and had not been at all implicated in any of the recent disturbances at the University— Mr Curtis also told me that he had been highly gratified with my Report to the Board of Overseers— When I came to the Stable; the man told me that at the first cry of Fire, my Coachman Wilson had gone off with the Carriage and Horses, without saying where— I went to Charles’s house, stopping first at the Tremont Hotel, to leave a Card for Mr R. H. Wilde, whom I had just before met in the Street— At the Tremont I met Mr. Horace Everett, Member of the House of Representative in Congress from Vermont, and one of the Committee of the House on the General Post-Office, authorised to sit during the recess; and he told me he was now going to Washington for that purpose. I met also Mr William Whipple of Providence, Rhode-Island, who asked for some Conversations with me, upon the election of a Senator of the United States, for that State; in the plan of Mr Knight, whose term expires on the 3d of March next— Mr Whipple is
a whig, and wishes for the election of Mr Green the Attorney General of the State— He says there is no chance of the election of Mr Burges, with which I told him that I should be perfectly satisfied—nor yet of Mr Potter, whose Jacksonism is too rank; but he fears that the Antimasons will go for Governor Francis, who he says is also a Jackson man— Mr Whipple seemed to wish that I should give some advice to the Antimasons of Rhode-Island not to vote for a Jackson man; but I did not think it right to meddle with their Elections at-all— Mr Wilde came in while we were talking; and I took the opportunity to withdraw. At Charles’s House I saw Mrs Field; but Wilson had not been there, and Charles had left no message to be delivered to me— I was going back to the Stable to see if Wilson had not returned there, when he with the Carriage overtook me in the Street— It was now more than half past two O’Clock— I had met Degrand in the Street; who proposed to come out to see me to-morrow: but I told him Mrs Adams was so exceedingly ill, that I could not invite him— I got home at 4 O’Clock, and found Walter Hellen, and Elizabeth C. Adams at dinner— Mrs Adams is yet most distressingly ill, and the Child Mary-Louisa this day is very sick— Mr Durant after three days of postponement, made his ascension in his balloon this afternoon— I saw his balloon for a few minutes as it was descending— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here in the Evening; and John Q. with whom Elizabeth went home.
14. VI. Sunday.

My wife’s illness continues with very little abatement; and still with extreme pain— My time is yet, not at my command, and my power of application suspended— Heard Mr Farley in the morning from John 16.33— “I have overcome the world”—and in the afternoon from Job 17.11. “My purposes are broken off”—a text which affected me more than the discourse which followed; to which as to that of the morning I found it impossible to give due attention— I read the fourth Sermon of the 6th. Volume of Saurin, upon the severity of God— The text, Hebrews 12.29. “For our God is a consuming fire”—and here I found the Preacher himself aware of the danger of the extent to which he had carried the doctrine of divine mercy, in the preceding Sermon, and which I had noticed last Sunday The express purpose of this one is to qualify that doctrine, by enlarging upon the divine Wrath, Vengeance or Justice—for there is after the manner of Saurin, a Metaphysical disquisition upon these terms, which require explanation, from the moment the reflection occurs that the deity cannot be affected by human Passions— Here as in many other instances, he states the difficulty with more energy than the solution, and remind me of a fly, sipping milk till he drops into the cup, and then swimming for his life without being able to get out— Saurin says that he cannot deny the possible sincerity of a death bed repentance, nor of course its efficacy to obtain pardon for the most atrocious crimes For he says that in about twenty thousand cases of such professed penitence of persons supposed dying but who have recovered, which he had witnessed or heard of; he has known two or three of real and effective reformation in after life— Altogether the two Sermons upon the divine mercies and the divine severity, do not form a clear and consistent system, nor are they satisfactory to my judgment.— How to reconcile them together and indeed all the attributes of the Godhead are beyond all mortal
comprehension— Canst thou by searching find them out?— Lieutt. T. B. Adams dined with us; and Walter Hellen spent the Evening at Mr Edward Miller’s— I employed as much of it as I could in writing.
15. V:30. Monday.

My wife’s illness continues unabated, and with few and short intervals even of partial relief.— Elizabeth C. Adams came to pass a few days here; and her mother Mrs T. B. Adams came this Evening to watch the Night. Lieutt. T. B. Adams had some conversation with me, respecting the Administration upon his father’s Estate, and the damages awarded against the Lowell Rail-road Company, for passing through the Medford farm. The Company had offered only 150 dollars— The County-Commissioners had allowed 250. and upon an Appeal, the Jury increased the allowance to 300 dollars which carried the costs of suit— As the suit was in my name, the fee of the land being mine, a receipt or order from me is necessary to the fulfilment of the decision— He spoke also of the House and farm in Braintree which were my brothers, and which he mortgaged to me, for more than it was worth— He retained possession with my consent of both the Estates during his life time— I took possession of both after his decease, subject to the equity of redemption, by his Heirs— His wife’s right of dower had not been renounced; and I determined that she should have the rents and profits of the whole of both Estates, intending further that after her decease they should go to her surviving children, as tenants in Common— She has accordingly enjoyed the rents and profits of both Estates, since my brother’s decease, and I consider the property as hers for life.— It was her wish, and it is mine that the damages recovered from the Lowell Rail-road Company, should be applied to discharge my brother’s debt to Dr Holbrook— It is the wish of the family that the Administration upon the Estate by J. M Gourgas should be closed— And if necessary that Letters of Administration de bonis non should be taken out by the Lieutt. but that will probably will not be needed— There were two men here this Evening, belonging to the fire Company, owners of the “Adams” Engine, who asked my permission to place their Engine-shed upon a corner of my Quincy Meadow— They said they paid a heavy ground rent for the spot on which it was now located; that they had been obliged at considerable cost to remove it last year, and were now required to move it again— I told them they might place it upon my lot, either at the Northern or Southern Corner, and I would give them a lease for five or ten years, for a pepper Corn rent, subject to two conditions— That if I should sell or loose the lot, they must then make their terms for the use of the land thereafter with the purchaser, or with my Lessee— They will see me again upon the subject— My Son Charles came out to dinner, and stays to Night— My morning was employed as steadily as I was able in writing, and after dinner in the garden— But I can give due attention to neither— I write with a mind absorbed in anxiety and alarm— I dig without method, spirit or heart— The time is now come that I should devote two or three hours of every afternoon to plantings, for the next Spring and Summer— I do accordingly plant and transplant, but so carelessly, that if I should live to return here next Spring, I fear I shall have no better recollection of my present plantations, than I have had after the interval of a Winter heretofore— The present affliction is almost an extinguisher of hope— Aequam memento servare mentem.
16. V:30. Tuesday.

My wife is no better— Mrs T. B. Adams who watched with her went home immediately after breakfast— Charles went to Boston, and Medford, and took Walter Hellen with him— I sent for Dr Holbrook to come, and attend with Dr. Woodward a consultation, upon the case of Mrs. Adams— They came at four O’Clock this afternoon, and held the consultation; but I had barely a moment to receive Dr Holbrook as we rose from dinner Mr Jotham Lincoln and Mr Solomon Lincoln came in; and not long afterwards Mr John Bailey; and engaged me in conversation till near Sunset— The two Lincolns are among the principal politicians of Hingham, and of the 12th. Congressional District; and the chief object of their call upon me was to ascertain whether it was my intention to decline a re-election to the House of Representatives— I told them it was not— They both expressed their Satisfaction at hearing this, and Solomon Lincoln said it was the general wish of the District that I should serve again: and that if I should decline, they would have great difficulty in agreeing upon a successor. Mr. Bailey was nominated by the recent Anti-masonic Convention for Governor of the Commonwealth the ensuing year, and I told him that as they could not bring themselves to support Mr Davis, they could not have made a choice more acceptable to me— He has accepted the nomination, but the evil consequence of that will be to prevent his re-election to the Senate of the State— He might indeed be voted for, to both the Offices at the same time; and as there is not a shadow of prospect that he will be chosen Governor and could scarcely fail of re election as a Senator, I was in hopes they would take that course— But he said he had no expectation of it, and did not believe it was the intention of any other person: as it would have the appearance of distrusting the success of the other election for Governor— My two nephews, and Mr Beale and his daughter Ann were here this Evening, and this stream of visitors disconcerted again the premeditated course of my occupations— It would also have deprived me of all my daily exercise, but that I had spent an hour of the morning in my Garden— Walking into it just after Breakfast, with Mrs T. B. Adams, she discovered a young snake, about two feet long coiled up on a bean vine in the central Alley. Her Son John Quincy killed it— Another had been killed yesterday, by Wilson, in the act of swallowing a small toad. I was obliged to snatch my hour for work in the Garden, which was therefore not well done.
17. V. Wednesday.

Another day mostly squandered— I sent Kirk into Boston very early for some Ice, and articles of Medicine ordered by Dr Holbrook for my wife. Fearing to lose my daily exercise, by waiting till after dinner, and being then disturbed by visitors, I went into the garden to work after breakfast, but had not been ten minutes there, when I was called back to see Mr Edward Everett and Mr Saul of New-Orleans—and while in conversation with them Mr S. B. Barrell came— Mrs Barrell was with him but hearing Mrs. Adams was very ill, she left the Chaise and walked homeward These Gentlemen kept me engaged till past One O Clock. Mr Beale had called and received 15 dollars in payment of the second Assessment on one Share in the Neponset Aqueduct Company. Kirk called by my direction on Dr Holbrook and asked him to come again to visit Mrs Adams—he accordingly came at 4 O’Clock— He thought her a little better than
yesterday— Dr Woodward saw her this morning, and I told him I had requested Dr Holbrook to come again—with which he declared himself entirely satisfied— I repeated my garden visit after dinner, but only gathered the Peaches, not yet ripe, but at least one half of the best of them had disappeared in the two last days— Three of my Seedling Peaches in the Garden and two in the Nursery bear this year, all fine fruit, and no two of them the same. Many of the Peaches have decayed before maturity; owing perhaps to the heavy rains— But there is one large and one small clingstone in the Garden, bearing fruit so beautiful, and so finely flavoured, that the light hand has already found them and nearly stripp’d the trees. I gathered the remnant save about half a dozen, which I left to take another chance. Lieutt. T. B. Adams dined with us, and then with his Sister Elizabeth visited at Mr T. Greenleaf’s. Elizabeth returned to tea, and with me spent the Evening in my wife’s chamber. The child Mary-Louisa was confined to her chamber with a bad cough—
18. IV. Thursday.

Though I rose so early: I occupied my time no better than usual. The morning was chilly and sultry; the midday at Summer heat, and the Evening sultry warm, with swarms of musquitos— I was much of the day in my garden, and Nursery, and found in the garden two bearing Peach trees with fine fruit, till now unobserved; and a last decaying Bartlett pear, hanging from a tree hidden by Hazel bushes, and Jerusalem Artichokes— I filled Earthen pot 6, with Seeds to be kept over Winter, and covered about 40 decaying Horse Plums, with fresh Earth, in a Potstand, to be kept till the Spring, and then planted— This is the second Season of fruit produced from my Seedling plantation, commenced in 1826—and it is encouraging to multiply my experiments— At noon, I bathed, at Mr Greenleafs wharf; but the water was so cold, that I remained in it less than five minutes— Charles came in with Walter Hellen, just as I was about to rise from dinner. Elizabeth had gone to Boston, with her brother, Lieutt. T. B— They returned after dark this Evening— Excepting my Diary and Index the labours of the day were lost. Dr Woodward was here this Morning, and with Dr Holbrook at 4 in the afternoon, in consultation— The violence of my wife’s disease has some what abated, but she is yet confined without intermission to her bed, with a continual variety of distressing Symptoms— Mary Louisa is still much troubled with her cough.
19. V. Friday.

No interruption of visitors, and I was thus enabled to write two pages, and to take a due portion of exercise. Dr Woodward was here this Morning, and Dr Holbrook this afternoon— The latter promised to call again on Sunday— I was twice in my garden and Nursery, and found my peaches had again been robbed in the Night— They are now nearly all gone—as are the Plums and Pears— I transplanted 3 seedling Pear-trees from Pot 8 to the Garden, but otherwise only buried some decayed fruit in the Earth— Most of the Plants are falling into the sear and yellow leaf— Charles went this afternoon to Medford, and Elizabeth C. Adams went home to her Mothers— Walter Hellen spent the Evening at Mr Edward Miller’s— I passed it in my wife’s chamber— Dr Holbrook thinks her essentially better, and out of danger, but she had a return of fever this Evening. I read some pages of G. Ticknors Memoir of La Fayette, and wrote an introductory Page; but the illness of my wife and that of the Child Mary-Louisa, which still continues wears upon my Spirits and leaves me no composure of mind for proper application to my task.
20. IV. Saturday.

My wife’s fever returned, with much severity, and an alarming variety of symptoms— The Child Mary-Louisa, keeps the chamber, with a teething cough, and fiery rash, which but partially comes out— These troubles act upon me as a spell, and unfit me for all mental exertion— I cannot sit ten minutes together, quiet at my writing table— I wander over my Garden and Nursery, without object or energy to improve observation, and I leave my most necessary occupation neglected— I had this day no interruption of visitors, and yet wrote scarcely a single page— I had come to the close of the year 1777. and was searching in Marshall’s Life of Washington, in Stedman’s History of the War, and in the Remembrancer for the atchievements of La Fayette in 1778. I find that most of his biographers in their zeal to exalt his character, represent him as having declined the offer of a Commission of Major-General, and insisted upon serving as a volunteer— The fact was not so, the truth is more conformable to the general Law of human nature, and not the less creditable to him— In a cursory glance over the Remembrancer of 1777 and 1778. I find many other reminiscences of the by-gone times which call up pleasing and painful reflections— The weather is at Summer heat, and my afternoon work in the Garden, was sluggish, and unprofitable— Lieutt. T. B. Adams dined with us, and his Sister Elizabeth came again in the Evening— Rufus Cogswell a pensioner here—
21. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Farley in the morning from 2. Corinthians 5.17 “Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold all things are become new.[”] This was a discourse upon regeneration, a doctrine very simple in itself and essentially characteristic of the Christian religion, but which has been mystified into gross absurdity and fanaticism by theologians. In this as in many other instances the wildest and most extravagant nonsense has been converted into creeds and Articles of faith, by assuming figurative language in a literal sense— The subject is so hacknied, that I take little satisfaction in hearing it treated, whether in the Calvinist or in the unitarian exposition— Mr Farley’s afternoon text was from 1. John 4.16. [“]And we have known and believed the love that God hath to us. God is love: and he that dwelleth in love dwelleth in God, and God in him. 17. Herein is our love made perfect, that we may have boldness in the day of judgment: because as he is, so are we in this world. 18. There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear, because fear hath torment. He that feareth is not made perfect in love.” Mr Farley himself is in Love, and his Sermons are all amiable. I had read the 5th. Sermon of the 6th. Volume of Saurin, upon the impeccability of the faithful— This is one of the excellent class, and from the reading of which I ought to have received edification— But my mind is too much distracted by the illness at once of my wife and of my grand-child for comfort or for application— Drs. Holbrook and Woodward were here in consultation, at four this afternoon— They think my wife much better, but she suffers still so severely and has returns of fever so distressing that I dare not hope with confidence— My own health is threatening, and I find my gardening is not exercise sufficient to warrant a total suspension of my walking— I therefore walked round Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s upland North of his house to the division black Oak between his farm and mine— Collected a few Tupelo Berries and Acorns, ripening— There are none on his red Oak tree— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here before Evening— Elizabeth went home, and Walter Hellen passed the Evening at Mr Edward Miller’s— I wrote to Dr Waterhouse.
22. IV. Monday.

My Son Charles’s son, is this day one year old—may the blessing of God preserve him to be a useful man in his day and generation— It was as beautiful an autumnal day, as I ever enjoyed and at five of the morning I sallied forth upon a six miles walk—1 to Arnold’s bridge 2 to the 8th mile stone on the old road 3. to the house on the hill of the cross road 4. to Neponset Corner 5 to Quincy’s gate 320 feet short 6 to my gate 480 feet short. I scarcely felt at all fatigued with this walk, but my time for working in the garden was abridged— I only planted in Box 2. a row of Tupelo Berries, black Oak Acorns and Office apple seeds, with Holbrook Bartlett Pear Seeds—and Mary-Louisa after dinner planted a Perkins Peach and Nectarine Stone, and 10 purple grape seeds— I gathered also the remainder of Horse Plums on the two trees in the Eastern Enclosure; which were ripe and in high perfection— I received a Letter from Commodore Charles Morris, enclosing one from the Secretary of the Navy, Mahlon Dickerson, to Captain J. J. Nicholson, directing him on taking the Command of the Potowmac frigate, to receive John Q. Adams jr. my nephew as a boy, and to assign to him Midshipman’s duty— This is all that it has been possible to obtain— The Potowmac frigate is now in Boston harbour, ready to sail on a three years cruise in the Mediterranean. John Quincy was here shortly after I received the Letters, which I gave him, advising him to prepare as speedily as possible for his departure— I received also a Letter from E. Kirby at Brownville, returning my Epitaph on General Brown; with the approbation of Mrs Brown, and others of the General’s Relatives to whom it has been submitted— Charles came out from Boston and found us at dinner— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here after dinner; and undertook to make a copy of the Epitaph, for the use of the Sculptor— Dr Woodward was here this Morning; and Dr Holbrook this afternoon— I made scarcely any progress with La Fayette— My dear wife is still confined to her bed, with constantly varying symptoms, and returning severe fever—and my own health menacing more than I am willing to express— I received also a Letter from B. F. Hallett.
23. V. Tuesday.

Took a Morning walk of four miles— From my house round by the 9th. Mile-stone to the opening of first quarry 1. Mile to opening of second Quarry 1 Mile—to Benjamin Bass’s house 1 Mile, short 320 feet and thence to my gate 1. Mile short 640 feet. I stop’d at B. Bass’s house, and spoke to him in his yard— He promised to come and settle his debt with me— Charles went in to Boston— Doctors Holbrook and Woodward were here in consultation— My wife’s illness continues without permanent abatement or relief; but Dr Holbrook says she is better, and that there is no danger— I spoke to him of the threatened cramps with which for some days past I have been seriously alarmed— He advised dry frictions and flower of Sulphur, but seemed to think not much of the complaint— I shall for the present confine myself to resumed exercise, the omission of which has made me puny. This however reduces much of my work in my Garden— I met Mr Beale this afternoon, who is clearing out the Brook in the low ground back of my house; and who wanted me to assist him— I was sluggish this afternoon in the Garden and Nursery— Set out 6 more slips of Hazel along the Eastern fence, but in ground too gravelly to expect they will leave— I set out also 7 slips of Quince, in one of the lower Western beds, and a row of 20 central Nursery Apple-tree seeds in Garden box 1. I suspend transplantations on account of the ground’s being now so dry. Lieutenant T. B. Adams and his brother John Q stop’d and took tea with us, on their return from Boston, where they went to see Captain Nicholson, but he has not yet arrived—
They went on board the frigate Potowmac, which is lying at Anchor in the stream, and are much pleased with her— Their Sister Elizabeth is sick— I found an autograph of my fathers, to send to the Princess Victoria— A copy in his own hand writing of his Letter to the Greffier of the States General, Fagel of 10. June 1785. announcing that he has been accredited, and received as Minister Plenipotentiary from the United States to the King of Great-Britain— I wrote also a Letter of Introduction for Sidney Brooks to Aaron Vail our Charge d’Affaires at London—but was much dissatisfied with my day’s work—
24. IV. Wednesday.

Walk to Germantown—to Brackett’s landing 1 mile, to the sands 2 to bound of my land on cross-road 3. to Germantown point 4—to the Mount Wollaston house round by the road is half an hours walk, and across through D. Greenleaf’s yard 24 minutes—my walk was 2 hours and 10 minutes, rather over 7 1/2 miles— I had not been at Germantown before, perhaps these forty years— General Palmers old house is yet standing in decay, but of his fine fruit garden there is left only a large orchard of old, but very good looking Apple-trees— I remember it well in its flourishing condition of 1775, and 6. and 7. when the general had on his elegant Chaise a painted racing greyhound, with the motto “perseverando.”— Alas! where is he? and where are all his projects, from the glass-house and the German Colony at Germantown, to the Salt works on Boston neck— All have vanished, but the Orchard and the Hardwick’s and Brieslers of Quincy— The two Doctors were here, and still pronounce my wife to be better, though her convalescence is extremely slow and with continual drawbacks— She received after a fortnight of anxious expectation of our son John and his family, a Letter from his wife, in bed with a bilious fever, which has been the cause of their detention— At my wife’s desire I wrote to John, advising them not to come on this Season, it being too late. I wrote likewise two other Letters of Introduction for Sidney Brooks, and sent them all to Charles— This cut off again my daily writing upon La Fayette; but I found Tarleton’s History of the Campaigns of 1780 and 1781. in which there is much concerning him, and to which I gave a cursory perusal— Elizabeth C. Adams returned here— I passed much of the afternoon in my Nursery and Garden where I planted in a row, 3. White Brattle Peach stones from Medford, with Office Apple-seeds St. Michael Pear Cores and other sundries— I thought I perceived live buds, shooting from two of the slips of hazel which I set out the 29th. of August— There are in spots about the Nursery ten seedling hazel bushes from Nuts—
25. IV. Thursday.

Six Miles morning walk—to Universalist Meeting house 1. Mile—to half-way cross road turning fromBaxters corner 2. to hill-top corner over Cross roads Bridge 3. to Turnpike corner Bridge 1 hour—to Braintree line Stone 4 miles to Episcopal Church Corner 5 to my gate 6— I think I find myself already better for these long morning walks the only objection to which is the time they consume— They cool my ardour for garden and Nursery labour, but furnish materials for my experiments. I found for example this morning upon a young black Oak tree, adjoining the Stoneline between Quincy and Braintree two small Acorns which I took and planted this afternoon in the Honey locust patch in my Garden, between two seedling Black walnuts; and with them I put down 2 Brattle white Peach stones from Medford—4 Tupelo Berries—purple grape seeds and Barberries, 5 cracked [symbols] Plum stones 1. Pear Core and sundry Apple seeds—of all which one or two trees may come up next Spring— Acorns, Chesnuts and Walnuts should be planted as soon as possible after
being gathered. Dr Holbrook and Dr Woodward were here— I answered a Letter from P. Hepburn of Montrose, Susquehanna County Pennsylvania, and enclosed to him, a copy of my 4th. of July Quincy Oration, at his desire, and some others of my printed productions— Lieutt. T. B. Adams went to Boston, with his brother J. Q. who brought me back a note from Charles with the Letters of introduction for Sidney Brooks— I enclosed them to him; and otherwise accomplished my day’s writing— My wife was again this morning more unwell, but better towards Evening—
26. IV:30 Friday

Seven miles morning walk— To Episcopal Church Corner 1. to the Quincy and Braintree line stone, on road to Randolph 2. to the valley between Braintree Meeting House and Solomon Thayer’s 3. Orchard hill top 1. hour. twelfth mile-stone 4 miles. Harvey Field’s over Penn’s Hill 5. Trask gate 6—and to my gate 3/4 of a Mile, which by going round the Trask lot, I made more than the 7th. mile— I was out 2 hours and 17 minutes; walking at my usual average of a mile in 17 minutes— My wife was this day better, and for a short time to leave her bed; but I did not get through my daily task— Lieutenant T. B. Adams brought me a fair copy of the monumental inscription for the tomb of General Brown. Elizabeth C. Adams went home definitively, and John Quincy came with a note from Boston, mentioning that Captain Nicholson had arrived there— I paid a lounging visit this afternoon to my garden, and planted about 20 decayed sugar Pears in a row on the border of the old walnut tree patch, with two Brattle white Peach Stones, Tupelo berries, Plum stones, and four Office Apples quartered— I gathered this morning 12 wild-Pears—2. Shell-bark walnuts and 3. Ash-seeds from the Trask lot trees. I read yesterday and this day the first and second Books of Armstrong’s Art of preserving health—upon Air and Diet—and I was ranging in the Diplomatic Correspondence of the Revolution, for the portion of La Fayette’s life, after his first return to France after the close of the Campaign of 1778.—but I did not succeed.
27. IV:30. Saturday.— Boston— Quincy.

I rode into Boston with John Quincy; stop’d at Mr James H. Foster’s, and invited one of his daughters to come out and spend some days with Mrs. Adams— I then went to the Tremont Hotel, and introduced my namesake to Captain Joseph J. Nicholson, to whom he delivered the order from the Secretary of the Navy, to receive him on board the Potowmack frigate as a boy to do Midshipman’s duty. Captain Nicholson received him very kindly and promised to take charge of him with pleasure— He said he had four other youths in the same capacity—one of them a son of Captain Perry, of the Navy, and another a son of Mr John Barney of Baltimore— He said he was then immediately going on board the ship, and offered to take John on board with him— He accordingly went with him, and after returning, took Louisa Foster out in the Chaise before dinner— I called for a few minutes at Charles’s Office, where I saw him; and then attended the adjourned meeting of the Committee of the Alumni of Harvard University— There were eleven members who attended the Meeting, John Lowell, myself, Thomas B. Wales, Joseph Story, Jacob Bigelow, George Hayward, Charles P. Curtis, Jonathan M. Wainwright, William H Gardiner, Stephen C. Phillips, and Robert C. Winthrop, though not
all at the same time— I proposed that Mr Lowell as the Senior Member of the Committee should take the Chair; but he would not consent, and it being, an adjourned meeting, I acted as Chairman— There was little discussion. Mr Lowell declared himself decidedly opposed to the object for which it was proposed to raise the funds,—and gave his reasons for his objections— He had prepared a draught of a Report stating that the Committee deemed the erection of a building to hold the Library, the most important want of the University—that a recent munificent bequest, (of Christopher Gore) would if applied to that purpose make large provision for that object, and that until it should be accomplished, it would be inexpedient to raise any fund by contribution from the alumni of the University— Judge Story made a warm and eloquent Speech in reply to Mr Lowell, repeating the arguments that he had urged at the last Meeting for cheapening the expense of Education, but observing that he was now satisfied that the whole project was impracticable, and that nothing could be done, he concluded by moving that the Committee should adjourn without day. I observed that as the Committee had been appointed by the Meeting for the discharge of a specific duty, I thought it would be incumbent upon them to make a report of some kind to the constituent body—That although I could not approve of raising a contribution for the object proposed by the Meeting; the purpose itself of raising a fund by the voluntary offerings of the graduates, to take effect at the period of the second century from the foundation of the College, and for the benefit of the University was one which I approved and cherished; and hoped might be still carried into execution— A report therefore might be made to the Meeting of next Commencement day, that the Committee finding the object prescribed by the last meeting impracticable, would recommend the raising of the fund for another object, and I would cheerfully contribute my aid and contribution to the erection of a building for the library. Three members of the Committee Daniel A. White of Salem, Theodore Lyman, now Mayor of Boston, and one other, had declined serving on the Committee— I proposed that the Committee should supply their places; but judge Story said that in that case he should also decline serving on the Committee and wished his place might also be supplied— After various remarks of several other members, it was finally voted to adjourn the Meeting of the Committee to the first Monday in August next, then to meet at 10 O’Clock in the morning at the same place, to make up a report to the general Meeting the day before the next Commencement— The Chairman, and the Secretary at the request of any two members of the Committee being authorised in the meantime, to call a special meeting of the Committee, if it should be necessary. The meeting adjourned before one O’Clock— I called again at Charles’s Office, and saw him; then paid a visit to Lieutenant Governor Armstrong, whom I found at home; and then went and dined at Mr James H. Foster’s— His brother at Portsmouth’s wife, his three sons, his son James’s wife and daughter, and his daughters Elizabeth and Mary were there— Louisa had gone out with John Quincy— At four O’Clock Gillet took me up in the Stage, and I came home with eight women and three children besides outside passengers— He came round by the new Settlement in Roxbury where there are nearly thirty houses built since the last Spring, looking like a new created City— Reached home after Sunset and found Louisa Foster here.
28. IV. Sunday.

Walked before breakfast round by the Blacksmith’s and Neponset Corners—Six Miles short 634 feet. Heard Mr Farley in the morning from Philippians 4.5. Let your moderation be known unto all men—and in the afternoon from Luke 22.32. [“]and when thou art converted Strengthen thy brethren”— This is the last day of Mr Farley’s engagement, and Mr Whitney gave
notice that the Communion would be administered the next Sunday— Miss Glover who has been for sometime the principal, and often the only female singer of the choir was there last Sunday, but was married in the Evening, and no longer appears— Boylston Adams’s daughter Abigail was alone there this morning, and this afternoon a new choir of twenty-two young girls took the place of miss Glover— I invited Mr Farley to dine with us, but he declined— Louisa C. Smith came to dinner, and Elizabeth C. Adams to tea— Mr Degrand came out after dinner and spent part of the Evening with me. Louisa Foster, and Walter spent it at Mr Edward Miller’s— I read the 6th. Sermon of the 6th Volume of Saurin, upon the decay of piety, with which I was not much charmed— I think his treatment of the subject not altogether the best— The papers brought out by Mr Degrand, announce the death of William H. Crawford, one of the men who has been bolstered up into Reputation in this Country, with very little proportional merit, and with a mass of demerit which happily for him will be buried in oblivion.
29. IV:30. Monday.

Walk to Doctor Holbrook’s house before Sunrise— The distance is 3 1/4 miles. which I walked in 53 minutes and took the same time to return— I count one thousand of my paces to a Mile, and a second of time for every pace— At 17 minutes to a Mile, it makes 1020 seconds for as many paces— But the weather being cold this morning I walked at the rate of a mile in 16 minutes. Dr Holbrook was not up— I requested his Servant man, not to disturb him; but when he should rise to say that I had called to ask him to visit Mrs Adams again, at his convenience in the course of the day— But to tell him that she was not worse than when he had last seen her— The man forgot the last part of his message, and the Doctor hearing that I had been at that early hour, to ask his attendance, hastened after me, and came within ten minutes after I got back from my walk. Miss Turner spent the day here— Charles came out from Boston this Evening—and Lieutt. T. B. Adams and John Quincy were here, both having been to Boston— The morning was very cool, and after a sweeping Northwest gale, the wind at Night lulled into a keen and clear atmosphere— I was great part of the afternoon at work in my Garden, and the first fire for the Season was made in our dining room.
30. V. Tuesday.

Morning walk of about five miles, two of which were to the houses of Ebenezer and Josiah Adams, the old spot where my Great-Grandfather Joseph Adams junr lived, and died—the remainder was through the fields, and over the hills— There was a sharp white frost and it was pinching cold— I found Chesnut and white Oak Acorns, not abundant; nor quite ripe—wild Pears from three different trees; all small, and apparently of the same kind: and white crab apples—with all these I propose to make the experiment of planting— But I lost the day, for the Garden. Walter Hellen left us, and went in the Stage to Boston— Thence to go to-morrow; returning to his mother at Alexandria— Doctor Waterhouse came from Cambridge and dined with us— He left us at four in the afternoon to reach home before dark— He is in his eightieth year, and in good bodily health, with every tooth sound in his head— His temper is cheerful, and his Spirit still lively, but his memory much decayed, of which he is conscious, and his judgment, more than ever under the ascendancy of his Passions— It amounts to little short of dotage— Mrs John Greenleaf and her daughter Mary Dawes were here this afternoon to see Mrs Adams— Louisa Foster spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— My time much wasted.
Day. No material variation from the two preceding Months— Except the morning walks of the last ten days— The arrears of my Diary Index are brought up.
